I should probably clarify, this is not to say that "novelty search" is not =
an interesting approach, it's just that as it currently stands, I do not se=
e what it can add above the standard taboo list searches coupled with stand=
ard and reproductively self governing approaches.

Regards,
-Gene

--- On W=
ed, 4/6/11, Gene Merdock <genemerdock@...> wrote:

From: Gene Merdock=
 <genemerdock@...>
Subject: Re: [neat] "Survive and Reproduce" as an =
Objective
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Date: Wednesday, April 6, 2011, 1:05 AM
=







=C2=A0



  


    
      
      
      Both environmental complexit=
y and Survive & Reproduce are aspects that have for at least a decade been =
explored and written about (core wars, polyworld...). For this reason I thi=
nk that "novelty search" is not really novel, the best it can achieve is to=
 be like Survive & Reproduce fitness function. What is meant by Survive & R=
eproduce in this context, is that the organism itself is responsible for it=
s reproductive cycle, like in polyworld for example, as opposed to a fitnes=
s function directly...

Regards,
-Gene

--- On Tue, 4/5/11, Colin Green <co=
lin.green1@...> wrote:

From: Colin Green <colin.green1@...>
Su=
bject: Re: [neat] "Survive and Reproduce" as an Objective
To:
 neat@yahoogr=
oups.com
Date: Tuesday, April 5, 2011, 11:55 PM







=C2=A0



    
     =
 
      
      Hi Ken,



On 4 April 2011 21:40, Ken <kstanley@...=
u> wrote:

>

> Colin, I wanted to branch my response to you to a new threa=
d because I want to focus

> on the idea that "survive and reproduce" is an=
 objective. This is not really an argument

> with anything you said, but m=
ainly a commentary on the meaning of "objective" that I

> think draws a us=
eful distinction.



I'm not sure I agree with the spirit of your argument =
but it's just a

gut feeling at this point so I'll have a go at clarifying =
my thoughts

a bit further and maybe I can home in a bit more on where I'm
=

disagreeing (if at all).



By 'survive' I mean - execute some strategy th=
at results in survival.

So find food and shelter, avoid danger, etc. Good =
survival strategy

for the domain =3D> good chance of surviving, bad strate=
gy =3D> lower

chance.



In an EA that survival *strategy* is 'do well on =
the fitness metric'

(aka objective) - because the only way to survive is t=
o get selected

by the EA's selection criteria. So I think we can clarify t=
he argument

by drawing a distinction between surviving/reproducing and

/s=
trategies/ that lead to surviving and reproducing. I think perhaps

we (or =
I) have conflated the two. Survive/reproduce is the high level

[implicit] =
objective that is always present, and survival /strategy/

is what we norma=
lly refer to as objective or goal in EC.



So far there's no distinction b=
etween nature/biology and EC. To my

mind nature has found complex /strateg=
ies/ for survival because:



A) Vastly more computational resource (or equ=
ivalent) [per unit time].

B) Vastly more time.

C) Vastly more complex dom=
ain.



It's this latter point that I feel has tended to be overlooked. If =
you

consider every living thing alive today and trace back through all of
=

their ancestors, then every single one of those zillions of organisms

exe=
cuted a successful strategy that lead to survival. Considerably

more organ=
isms not on that family tree didn't survive - so the natural

world does tr=
y out unsuccessful strategies, but only for one

generation at a time, it d=
oesn't create offspring with variations on

those poor strategies in the ho=
pe of finding something better. What

does happen though is that stragies a=
re so complex (for creatures with

large brains anyway) that they can incor=
porate successful parts (find

food) and yet waste much time on poor sub-st=
rategies (effectively

stragey efficiency). Evolution will select for effic=
iency but unlike

survival it's not a binary yes/no thing, it's more probab=
ilistic, so

more like the small low scoring species in NEAT (from fitness
=

sharing).



It's perhaps those poor side strategies that fit your idea of=


searching with no objective, they piggy back on for the ride and very

oc=
casionally become useful. Where EC tends to fall short IMO is that

the dom=
ain complexity is vastly lower than the natural world so

there's less oppo=
rtunty for exploring variations in strategy -

branching off into multiple =
successful branches and sub-branches

without a major loss in fitness on th=
e objective. Put another way, the

natural world's fitness landscape is dom=
inated by smooth undulations

in all dimensions, whereas EC objectives tend=
 to have a few

sharp/steep local maxima.



Nature also provides a gentle =
selection pressure towards complex

strategies by providing resources that =
require increasingly complex

strategies to reach - you can't eat those lan=
d plants until you evolve

legs ang lungs. And you can't eat those omnivore=
s without evolving

good eyes and fast/strong muscles, etc. but the plants =
and meat were

there as an untapped resource until that first legged creatu=
re and

first carnivore came along. So we can see now that framing the

sur=
vival as being an objective that's been achieved on day one misses

a lot o=
f the key dynamics that drive evolution. Surviving is the high

level impli=
cit objective, some species have not moved on from floating

in the sea eat=
ign CO2 and sunlight, but other strategies were evolved

to tap into new pr=
eviously untapped resources - and that climb from

simple to complex resour=
ces utilisation continues to this day.



Colin.



    
     



 







=

ective) - because the only way to survive is to get selected<br>

[implicit] objective that=
 is always present, and survival /strategy/<br>
is what we normally refer t=
o as objective or goal in EC.<br>
<br>
So far there's no distinction betwee=
n nature/biology and EC. To my<br>
mind nature has found complex /strategie=
s/ for survival because:<br>
<br>
A) Vastly more computational resource (or=
 equivalent) [per unit time].<br>
B) Vastly more time.<br>
C) Vastly more c=
omplex domain.<br>
<br>
It's this latter point that I feel has tended to be=
 overlooked. If you<br>

ack through all of<br>
their ancestors, then every single one of those zill=
ions of organisms<br>
executed a successful strategy that lead to survival.=
 Considerably<br>

o the natural<br>

one<br>

n<br>
those poor strategies in the hope of finding something better. What<b=
r>
does happen though is that stragies are so complex (for creatures with<b=
r>
large brains anyway) that they can incorporate successful parts (find<br=
>
food) and yet waste much time on poor sub-strategies (effectively<br>
str=
agey efficiency). Evolution will select for efficiency but unlike<br>
survi=
val it's not a binary yes/no thing, it's more probabilistic, so<br>
more li=
ke the small low scoring species in NEAT (from fitness<br>
sharing).<br>
<b=
r>
It's perhaps those poor side strategies that fit your idea of<br>
search=

nally become useful. Where EC tends to fall short IMO is that<br>

n complexity is vastly lower than the natural world so<br>

ortunty for exploring variations in strategy -<br>
branching off into multi=

without a major loss in fitnes=

natural world's fitness landsc=
ape is dominated by smooth undulations<br>
in all dimensions, whereas EC ob=
jectives tend to have a few<br>

<br>
Nature a=

 So we can see now that framing the<br>
